moves.1. d4: The amateur opens with the QP, hoping to prolong his resistance by playing a positional, slow game.
moves.2... e6: Bruening plays an Orthodox defense in response.
moves.3. Bf4: The amateur forgets the rule: Knights before Bishops. 3 N-QB3 is the move he should make.
moves.3... c5: Bruening takes advantage of this with an immediate challenge to the center.
moves.4. Nc3: One move too late. Now Bruening can do...
moves.5. Bxb8: The best move was to retreat the QN.
moves.5... dxc3: Now Bruening's advanced Pawn becomes threatening.
moves.6. Be5: 6 R-N1 or 6 PxP would drag out the game a bit.
moves.6... cxb2: Threatens PxR (Q) and B-N5 ch winning the White Q. White cannot defend both threats, so he resigns at once.
